heading: investors get cold feet
subheading: the dow takes a dive on fears that third quarter earnings will fall short of expectations. the dow's 231-point drop is its biggest in nearly five months.
author: reuters
text: stocks fell sharply tuesday as wall street feared that it may have set the bar too high for third quarter earnings expectations. the dow jones industrial average ended down 231.12 points, or 2.17 percent, at 10,417.06."i think we have seen in the past couple of years expectations being surpassed so often that the expectations themselves become very unrealistic," said peggy farley, president of ascent/meredith asset management.farley said the market was also glum with concerns about money flowing out of the united states and additional interest rate hikes after the federal reserve said last week it was learning toward raising rates.analysts downplayed the immediate impact on markets of news that prime minister nawaz sharif's government in pakistan, which is a nuclear power, had been toppled in an apparent military coup."this is really a classic case of no buyers," said charles payne, head analyst at wall street strategies. "the companies that did do well as far as earnings are concerned are not generating a lot of enthusiasm. [the coup] is part of the puzzle but it is such a small piece that we cannot blame a 200-point sell-off on pakistan."among the biggest losers was defense and aerospace giant raytheon, which fell 19 7/8 to 22 1/8 after the company warned its earnings this year and next would fall short of expectations.the selloff brought down the rest of the sector, with general dynamics (gd) down 4 11/16 at 57 11/16, lockheed martin corp. off 1 13/16 at 28-9/16, and boeing (ba) was down 2 5/16 at 39 5/8.in the broader market, declining issues outnumbered advances 21 to 8 on moderate volume of 772 million shares on the new york stock exchange.the nasdaq composite index lost 43.52 points, or 1.49 percent, at 2,872.43, a day after ending at record high of 2,915.95.the s&p 500 index was down 22.17 points, or 1.66 percent, at 1,313.04. the 30-year us treasury bond fell 16/32, boosting the yield to 6.23 percent from 6.20 percent on friday. the bond market was closed monday for the columbus day holiday.the 30-stock dow index was bruised with only two components, oil major chevron and international paper (ip), the world's largest paper company, in positive territory.chevron was up 1-1/8 at 88 and ip, which posted earnings that topped expectations, up 3/16 at 48-11/16.analysts were focusing on a speech by a federal reserve governor for further clues on whether the fed will hike interest rates again at its 16 november meeting.federal reserve governor laurence meyer was expected to deliver an address "new challenges for monetary policy: the view from jackson hole" at the university of missouri after the market's close.last week, the fed's policy setting stopped short of raising rates, but said it was leaning toward raising rates in the future.among the companies that posted better-than-expected earnings were wall street investment firms, which ended on a mixed note.merrill lynch slipped 1/8 to 67, painewebber group (pwj) closed off 11/16 at 35, and donaldson lufkin & jenrette was up 2 3/16 at 42 1/2.chipmaking giant intel (intc) closed up 3/16 at 76 11/16. after the close, it reported third quarter earnings of 55 cents a share, excluding acquisition charges. analysts had been expecting intel to earn 57 cents a share from continuing operations, according to first call/thomson financial.wireless equipment maker motorola (mot) lost 1 11/16 at 94 15/16 ahead of its earnings, expected after the close.elsewhere, drug store chain rite aid (rad) said it expects to post a loss and its stock dropped 2 5/16 to 10 1/2.timber, pulp, and building materials company weyerhaeuser (wy) had earnings that topped wall street expectations, pushing the stock up 1-1/16 to 60-1/2.copyright
